stream_context.summary: Kaze continues building the Wild West course content while simultaneously undertaking a major engine-level change: rewriting Mario’s collision/step system. The stream includes integrating Zeina’s new texture assets (a wanted-poster bulletin board), showing the now-finished minecart chase mission, prototyping the next “bank robbery / Monty Mole tunnel” mission flow, and demonstrating a new quality-of-life feature: auto-sizing dialogue boxes to fit longer text (useful for songs and localization).
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces a foundational collision/step-system rewrite (with rationale vs prior approaches), completes and showcases a mission (minecart chase), adds a dialogue-system feature that impacts writing/localization, and captures an in-progress level-flow decision about how players discover the bank tunnel entrance.

findings.summary: Kaze began rewriting Mario’s collision/step handling from scratch; the stream runs on a new step function that already improves general interactions but still has bugs (notably ceiling behavior and occasional incorrect roll-out-to-kick transitions).

He explains why previous collision approaches were insufficient: the original SM64 step logic “allows multiple clips”; a prior raycast-physics approach reduced some clipping but introduced cases where Mario could be pushed below ceilings or required overly short steps. The new approach binary-searches for the largest viable step, uses raycasts to accelerate the search, and adds move-verification checks (floor/vertical clearance) for safety and speed.

Kaze considers the minecart mission “finished” and shows it: a hidden door in the bar leads to a chase/minigame sequence where enemies get closer over time; straying too far from the tracks triggers a fade-out death; stepping in front of a minecart can run Mario over.
The minecart mission demo crashes due to the new collision functions not being fully finished, indicating the collision rewrite is currently destabilizing playtesting in some areas.

Spin-jump presentation choice: Kaze disliked the “twirl” and chose a spin-jump animation inspired by Mario’s Down-B from Smash Melee as the closest ‘official’ 1996-era reference. Zeina animated it; Kaze polished it. He’s uncertain about a Smash-derived voice line because it feels noticeably non-SM64, and he floats hiring a voice actor (e.g., Fiverr) as an alternative.
findings.quote: The closest you have to an official version of the spin jump from 1996 is Mario's Down-B from Smash Melee.

findings.summary: To implement the Wild West bulletin board/wanted posters, Kaze converts textures into fog-shaded decals and corrects render settings (avoiding ‘environment’ color defaults that caused bugs elsewhere). He diagnoses blurry/incorrect poster rendering as coordinate quantization and fixes it by ensuring decals share exact coordinates and aligning them to a world axis.

Kaze demonstrates a new dialogue feature not present in the original SM64: text boxes can automatically resize to fit the full string (e.g., if an NPC ‘sings’ longer text), removing the need for manual sizing and improving usability for translation/localization.
findings.quote: It will automatically find the right size to encapsulate the text.

findings.summary: For the next Wild West mission (bank robbery / Monty Mole tunnel), Kaze identifies a pacing/readability problem: players might stumble into the tunnel/boss sequence without understanding the robbery context. He iterates on how to guide discovery (NPC hints + environmental cues) while preventing accidental entry.

Kaze and chat iterate on gating the tunnel entrance. He initially likes a comedic ‘fake cardboard boulder/cloth’ concept but rejects it as too obvious and too costly to implement convincingly (cloth physics + interaction). He lands on a straightforward design: a breakable boulder gated by the Bomb Cap (also helping tie caps into progression), plus hinting via particles and NPC dialogue about the tunnel.
findings.quote: I think just ground pounds a rock here is the most sane and the best option.

findings.summary: Kaze articulates a core goal for Return to Yoshi’s Island: SM64’s movement is brilliant, but many original levels feel like generic ‘places’ without a strong theme. He aims to keep the movement feel while improving level identity (theme/vibe) and making worlds feel like they exist independently of Mario.
findings.quote: I don't think Mario 64 is that great either, except for the movement design.

findings.summary: He reinforces a deliberate content-structure choice: not every level will be story-heavy. The game mixes levels with story and character interactions and levels that are more purely ‘places’ Mario visits, to avoid making every course feel built specifically for the player-character.
findings.quote: We don't want every level to feel like it's made for Mario. We want a lot of them to feel more like they are there and Mario is experiencing them.

findings.summary: Kaze mentions there are “like three and a half levels left” and begins reconsidering course ordering to improve pacing—specifically noting the last planned courses skew toward ‘natural places’ rather than Mario-centric or story-driven levels, and he makes a note about moving the Wild West course to Course 13 / adjusting Course 12.
Progression/collectible structure note: Yoshi coins replace 100-coin stars; there are no 100-coin challenges in this project.

biobak.summary: Biobak contributes to the level-design discussion by agreeing with/echoing the critique about ‘placeness’ in SM64 and is specifically called out by Kaze as someone who will benefit from the new auto-sizing dialogue boxes for translation/localization.
Kaze notes Biobak is producing substantial content for the hack (assets/level work), though specifics aren’t enumerated in this stream.

badub.summary: Kaze reiterates Badub is producing a lot of music for the project, but no specific new track delivery or implementation occurs in this stream.

zeina.summary: Zeina created the spin-jump animation (Melee-inspired), with Kaze doing final polish.
Zeina provides art assets for the Wild West bulletin board/wanted posters; Kaze discovers missing/bundling issues and then integrates the textures into fog-shaded decals.
Zeina is involved in the Koopa banker NPC look (glasses/cane suggestions and texture ideas), though Kaze makes final calls based on N64 rendering constraints.

key_stories.title: Replacing SM64’s step/collision logic mid-development
key_stories.summary: Kaze starts a ground-up rewrite of Mario’s collision/step system and is already running the game on it. He frames it as essential for making Return to Yoshi’s Island feel better than existing SM64 hacks in moment-to-moment movement, even if it temporarily introduces crashes and edge-case bugs.
key_stories.challenge: The original step logic permits clipping; a prior raycast-based approach reduced some issues but caused new ones (ceiling problems, unsafe step compromises).
key_stories.process: He removes the old step system and builds a new one that binary-searches for the largest valid step, uses raycasts for speed, and performs additional move-verification checks (floor + vertical clearance).
key_stories.outcome: Movement interactions feel improved, but ceiling behavior and occasional animation/state bugs remain; at least one crash during the minecart mission is attributed to the unfinished collision rewrite.
key_stories.key_quote: Once my new collision system is done, dude, this game will be so nice collision-wise.

key_stories.title: Designing readable discovery for the bank robbery tunnel
key_stories.summary: While planning the next Wild West mission, Kaze realizes players might enter the tunnel/boss sequence without understanding the ‘bank robbery’ setup. He explores comedic gating (fake cardboard/cloth cover) but shifts toward a clearer, more traditional gate tied to an underused mechanic.
key_stories.challenge: Make the entrance discoverable through narrative/environmental logic, but not so visually ‘fake’ that players stumble into it immediately without context.
key_stories.process: He proposes NPC dialogue that explains the robbery and points at the tunnel, plus environmental particle hints; he evaluates fake-cover concepts (cardboard/cloth) and rejects them as too obvious or too hard to implement convincingly (cloth interaction/physics).
key_stories.outcome: He decides on a breakable boulder entrance gated by the Bomb Cap, aligning progression with cap usage while keeping the entrance thematically plausible.
key_stories.key_quote: I want players to seek out the hole, you know.

open_questions.topic: Collision rewrite scope, testing, and risk management
open_questions.context: Kaze is mid-transition to a new collision/step system that changes core movement behavior and can cause crashes (seen during the minecart demo).
questions: What specific player-facing problems (clips/softlocks) convinced you the old step/collision approach was beyond patching, and when did you first realize a full rewrite was necessary?
How are you validating the new collision system across the whole game (test levels, automated cases, known-problem spots), and what’s your ‘done’ criterion before you stop iterating?
What was the biggest unexpected bug from the rewrite so far (e.g., ceiling behavior, roll-to-kick state), and what did it teach you about SM64’s original assumptions?
How much did this rewrite affect schedule/level production, and how do you decide when engine work is worth the disruption?
You mention the new approach is faster—where does the performance win come from on N64 hardware, and what does that headroom let you do elsewhere?

open_questions.topic: Spin jump: authenticity vs new identity (animation + voice)
open_questions.context: Kaze chose a Melee-inspired spin jump (animation + a Melee voice line) because other options looked wrong, but he’s unsure if the voice reads as ‘not Mario 64’ and considers hiring a voice actor.
questions: What were the alternative spin jump animation concepts you tried, and what exactly made them feel ‘wrong’ in SM64’s visual language?
How do you decide when to reuse ‘official’ Nintendo references (Melee) versus creating something fully original—what’s your rule of thumb for ‘respectful’ vs ‘out of place’?
If you do hire a voice actor, what direction would you give them: imitate SM64-era Mario, or fit the new tone of Return to Yoshi’s Island even if it diverges?
How important are small audiovisual cues (voice snippets, sfx, animations) to making the hack feel cohesive rather than like a collage of Nintendo sources?

open_questions.topic: Dialogue auto-sizing feature and localization plans
open_questions.context: Kaze adds a system that automatically sizes text boxes to fit longer strings; he explicitly notes Biobak may like it for translation.
questions: What was the pain point that made you build auto-sizing dialogue now—was it song text, NPC writing volume, or anticipated translation needs?
Do you plan to ship official translations, and if so, which languages and who would own that workflow?
Are there any remaining hard constraints in your dialogue system (line breaks, fonts, special characters, box placement) that translators/writers must work around?
How does auto-sizing interact with camera framing and gameplay readability—are there cases where you still need manual control?

open_questions.topic: Wild West bank robbery mission readability and gating
open_questions.context: Kaze worries players will find the tunnel entrance without understanding the robbery plot; he iterates from comedic fake-cover ideas to a Bomb Cap breakable boulder plus hints (NPC + particles).
questions: What’s the intended ‘player understanding sequence’—what do you want them to know before they ever see the tunnel entrance?
How will you tutorialize or remind players about the Bomb Cap at this point in the game so the boulder gate reads as a solvable problem instead of a wall?
What specific environmental hinting will you use (particles, framing, coin trails, NPC sightlines), and how do you test whether it’s too subtle or too obvious?
Does the bank robbery resolve into a boss fight immediately, or will there be intermediate gameplay beats inside the tunnel to build anticipation?
What made you reject the cardboard/cloth gag in the end—was it primarily implementation cost, player readability, tone, or all three?

open_questions.topic: Course pacing/order changes late in production
open_questions.context: Kaze notes ~3.5 levels remain and considers rearranging course order for more even pacing between ‘Mario-centric’ levels and ‘place-first’ levels; he makes a note about moving Wild West to Course 13 / adjusting Course 12.
questions: What is the current intended course order (especially Courses 11–15), and what problem are you trying to solve by swapping Course 12/13?
When you say some levels are ‘made for Mario’ versus ‘Mario experiences them,’ what criteria do you use to categorize a course?
How do pacing and difficulty progression interact with narrative progression in your planning—are those separate tracks or tightly coupled?
What’s the final decision-making process for course-order changes: who weighs in (you, Zeina, Biobak), and what evidence changes your mind (playtests, gut feel, feedback)?
